ECONOMIC QUESTIONS.A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for Dominion Affairs (C.P.-299 (30)) in regard to the pro-cedure at the forthcoming ImperialConference.Reference:Cabinet 49(30), Con-clusion 2 ,)A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for India (CP.-306 (30))suggesting that the draft statute of Westminster should be amended so as to leave the United Kingdomfree to make India a dominion of the kind to which this Billapplies, whenever this course is thought right, and in themeantime, if necessary, to callher a Dominion, without in either case the assent of the otherDominions being required.A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for the Colonies CP.-290(30)) urging that, in view of thelarge and ever-growing importance ofthe Colonies, Protectorates and mandated Territories as e con-stituent part of the Empire, itwould give a better appearanceif the Secretary of State responsi-ble for then; sat as a full zsezitberof the United Kingdom delegation at the Conference, that is, "for political and general questions"instead of "for economic questions"only, as decided by the Cabinet onJuly 23rd (Cabinet 44 (30)). The Cabinet were impressed by the difflcul-ties created by the Report of the ImperialConference of' 1926, and more particularly by the emphasis laid on equality of status between GreatBritain and the Dominions and the keeping in the background of the principle of co-operation, whichis a necessary supplement to the other. Thatfundamental difficulty had been accentuated bythe Report of the Conference on the Operation ofDominion Legislation, etc., of 1929, which wasin effect an attempt to write by lawyers a very complicated Constitution which had better never have been written at all, or in any event agreedto by political minds. It was recognised thatthe details of the Report of 1929 were logicallyconsistent with the results of the Conference of1926, but, considered as a whole,, the results were felt by the Cabinet to be highly unsa.tisfact-ory and, it was thought, would not commend them-s elv ss to sou,e of the Dominions. k-The Cabinet felt that the complications of thepresent position were well illustrated by theIndian difficulty raised in the Memorandum by theSecretary of State for India f CP,-306 (30)).the Statute of Westminster were drafted in itspresent form, India would appear to be excludedfrom the status of a Dominion, which could onlycause reactions of a most unfortunate characterin India. If, on the other hand, provision wasmade to enable India to become a Dominion, hopesmight be raised which possibly could not, at thepresent time, be satisfied. The Cabinet recog-nised also that the discussion of the Statute o^-g- Westminster, in its present shape, would strengthen the right of the Dominions to claim that they must be consulted before a Colony was raised to the status of a Dominion. In this con-nection the Cabinet were reminded that the admissionof India to the Imperial Conference in 1917 hadbeen decided on only after a resolution had been moved by the Prime Minister of Canada, seconded bythe Priroe Minister of New Zealand, and passed- bythe Imperial 1J!'"ar Conference, and that the resolutionhad been subject to the concurrence of the Govern-rnents concerned. As a further fact to be remembered,it was pointed out that India was represented atthe Imperial Conference, as well as at the League ofNations and at the recent London Naval Conference,and at these occupied the same position as a Doijjinior.On the other hand, the Irish Free State had been admitted as a Dominion without consultation with theImperial Conference.
